title: Skip
message:
I cleaned this up and built a ready-to-drop-in page with a responsive Foundation layout, dark theme, and a data-driven list of writing samples. It’s in the canvas to the right—swap in your real headshot/CV/email and keep adding links in the `WRITING_DATA` array.

Quick highlights:
- Proper fonts + preconnect, accessible colors, and no protocol-relative URLs.
- Sticky-nav safe: the page auto-adds top padding based on `#navbar` height.
- Hero row: headshot (left) and name/roles/bio + buttons (right) using Foundation’s grid.
- Writing sections render from JS data (simple list by default). Flip to a card grid by switching to `renderCards(mount)`. Cards use a lightweight favicon as a thumbnail fallback to avoid brittle OpenGraph scraping.
- Small, modern touches: lazy images, semantic markup, `rel=noopener`, and minimal, reusable styles.

If you want me to:
- auto-pull titles/outlets/years from pasted URLs,
- switch to a JSON file and fetch it,
- or integrate this with your existing top-bar include,

say the word and I’ll wire it up.

title: Skip
message:
I cleaned this up and built a ready-to-drop-in page with a responsive Foundation layout, dark theme, and a data-driven list of writing samples. It’s in the canvas to the right—swap in your real headshot/CV/email and keep adding links in the `WRITING_DATA` array.

Quick highlights:
- Proper fonts + preconnect, accessible colors, and no protocol-relative URLs.
- Sticky-nav safe: the page auto-adds top padding based on `#navbar` height.
- Hero row: headshot (left) and name/roles/bio + buttons (right) using Foundation’s grid.
- Writing sections render from JS data (simple list by default). Flip to a card grid by switching to `renderCards(mount)`. Cards use a lightweight favicon as a thumbnail fallback to avoid brittle OpenGraph scraping.
- Small, modern touches: lazy images, semantic markup, `rel=noopener`, and minimal, reusable styles.

If you want me to:
- auto-pull titles/outlets/years from pasted URLs,
- switch to a JSON file and fetch it,
- or integrate this with your existing top-bar include,

say the word and I’ll wire it up.
switching to a json seems good. Also how do you <!-- Choose ONE presentation style: simple lists OR cards. -->

I need to update the canvas code to fetch JSON data and add a toggle for switching between list and card views, using localStorage for persistence. The JSON gets fetched from /data/writing.json, with categories and items like title, outlet, year, etc. We’ll implement this in JS, replacing WRITING_DATA with fetch, plus adding controls and rendering logic. I'll also ensure to handle CORS issues and fallback if fetching fails.

Great call on moving to JSON—and you don’t have to pick just one presentation style anymore. I wired up both and added a simple toggle.

Here’s what changed (it’s already in the canvas):

1) Data now loads from a JSON file
- Create `/data/writing.json` (same origin as the page).
- Structure:

```json
[
  {
    category: Concert Reviews,
    items: [
      {
        title: From Marsalis to Schubert: The Philadelphia Orchestra at Hill Auditorium,
        outlet: PULP: Arts Around Ann Arbor,
        year: 2024,
        url: https://pulp.aadl.org/node/583798,
        thumb:   // optional
      }
    ]
  },
  { category: Book Reviews, items: [] },
  { category: Profiles, items: [] },
  { category: Newsletters, items: [] },
  { category: Academic Writing, items: [] }
]
```

- The page fetches that file (`/data/writing.json`) and renders it. If a `thumb` isn’t provided, it falls back to the site’s favicon.

2) Toggle between list and cards (no rebuild needed)
- A little “View: [List] [Cards]” toolbar appears above the sections.
- Click to switch views; your choice persists via `localStorage`.
- No more “choose one” in code—you can flip views anytime.

Notes:
- Keep `/data/writing.json` on the same domain (avoids CORS headaches).
- If you want me to scrape title/outlet/year from URLs automatically, I can add a one-time script to pre-fill your JSON from a list of links.
